citation.article-title: Peptostreptococcus barnesae sp. nov., a Gram-positive, anaerobic, obligately purine utilizing coccus from chicken feces.

p.s: Description of Peptostreptococcus barnesae sp. nov.
Peptostreptococcus barnesae (bar'nes. ae. ML. gen. noun barnesae of Barnes, named for Ella M. Barnes, who has contributed much to the knowledge of the avian intestinal microflora)
Spherical cells, 0.5 to 0.9 μm in diameter, usually paired, with slime capsules, may form aggregations of 4 to 6 cells, non-motile, non-sporeforming.
Colonies are non-pigmented, flat, circular, and reach a diameter of 3 to 4 mm.
Gram-positive.
Physiology.
Strictly anaerobic; optimum temperature 37 to 40°C growth at 20 to 40°C pH range for growth 7.0 to 9.0, optimum at 7.5 (strain HKB-3) and 8.0 (strains HKB-2 and -5), respectively; chemoorganotrophic.
Utilizes purines such as uric acid, 6,8-dihydroxypurine, guanine, hypoxanthine, and xanthine; adenine and glycine utilized, but not readily.
Selenite, molybdate, and tungstate, vitamins or 0.01% yeast extract are required for growth, but not Tween 80.
Acetate, formate, ammonia, and CO2 are products.
Hydrogen, sulfide, acetoin, diacetyl, 2,3-butanediol, and butyrate are not produced, indole formation might be feeble.
Nitrate is not reduced.
Hydrolysis of gelatin, starch, and esculin does not occur.
No hemolysis was observed.
Catalase, lecithinase, and urease are not produced, however, lipase.
Growth is enhanced in the presence of bile salts.
The peptidoglycan contains glycine in position 1 and lysine in position 3 and is crosslinked by D-aspartate.
The guanosineplus- cytosine content of the DNA is 33.6 to 34.8 mol% (thermal denaturation method).
Type strain.
HKB-5.
The strain was isolated from fresh chicken feces obtained from a commercial laying hen plant in Göttingen, FRG.
The G + C content of the DNA is 33.6 mol% (thermal denaturation method).
The strain has been deposited in Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen, Göttingen, FRG, under the accession number DSM 3244.
